turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Peitho.
turn.1: What role did Peitho play in Greek tragedy?
turn.2: In "Eumenides", Athena thanks Peitho after convincing the Furies of her reasoning in acquitting Orestes and successfully defusing the strife.
turn.3: Is there anything else interesting about Peitho in Greek tragedy?
turn.4: However, Peitho may be a destructive force when used for seduction or selfish personal gains, such as in "Agamemnon" where Clytemnestra curses Peitho for Paris’s stealing of Helen, and she uses persuasion convince Cassandra to enter the house in order to murder her.
turn.6: Pausanias reports that after the unification (synoikismos) of Athens, Theseus set up a cult of Aphrodite Pandemos and Peitho on the south slope of Acropolis of Athens.
turn.8: In recognition of this myth, both goddesses were worshipped in the Attic Aphrodisia Festival.
turn.9: Anything else interesting in the article?
turn.10: Peitho was worshipped as the goddess of both sexual and rhetorical persuasion in Athens from the 4 century into the Roman Imperial era, the time of Pausanias’s writing.
turn.11: Was there anything else on the list of gods?
turn.12: However, some scholars believe it is possible that worship dates to the 6 century, but there is not strong evidence for this assertion.
